However, I do not think it is sensible to pass amendments as detailed as this literally telling the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Department of the Treasury and others involved in the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development step by step how they should go about assessing the ecological and environmental aspects of loans of this type. They already do so; they already have meetings about this matter and it is part of the conditions of IMF loans.

Secondly, I certainly cannot agree that the Australian Government should go into detail about the potential environmental problems and inadequacy of measures in other countries. We get into enough trouble in this country doing that in Tasmania and Queensland let alone trying to do it in sovereign nations throughout the world. Our Tasmanian colleagues complain about a little interference in Tasmania even though it is part of this country. Senator Mason wants us to tell everyone in the world how to conduct his business.

I take into account the fact that the amendment was put in a serious way and that the points made by Senator Mason are serious points. I accept that they are serious points; I accept that mistakes of the type he has put forward have been made. However, for the reasons I have stated I cannot accept this amendment even though it is the largest amendment ever put forward in the Senate. I am afraid it will be the largest amendment ever defeated in the Senate. I urge honourable senators to support the International Financial Institutions (Share Increase) Bill 1986 unamended.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Mason's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1986OVERSEAS STUDENTS CHARGE COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any private overseas student studying in Australia needs to consider at least two questions. The first is whether the Government of this country intends to move towards full cost recovery for education services provided to those students. The second question is: If a government does intend so to move, at what rate?

SPEECH.PARA: The Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1986 and the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill 1986 which we are now considering seek, firstly, to increase a variety of charges; secondly, to increase some of those charges by very large amounts; and, thirdly, to extend the charges to new groups of students. The charges will range fairly considerably, from $300 annually for private overseas students in secondary schools, through $740 for private overseas students studying in technical and further education institutions, up to amounts of $5,506 yearly for students of medicine, dentistry and veterinary science who start their courses after 1 January 1986.

The matters for consideration by the Senate are the two issues that I raised above. The first is whether it is appropriate to move towards full cost recovery. The second is what is an appropriate rate at which to move. I will consider those two questions in order. The first, whether it is appropriate to move towards full cost recovery for private overseas students, requires some consideration of the philosophy which should underlie our acceptance of and welcome to students from other countries. I start with the proposition that Australia does have international obligations and regional responsibilities which extend to offering educational services to people living in our region and from overseas.

It is my contention and the contention of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia that those obligations are best met in the area of education by the provision on a generous basis of free places on an agreed government to government basis and covered explicitly in the foreign aid vote. That is the approach that was taken by Sir Gordon Jackson in the report of the Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program which he put down and which dealt with the question of private overseas students. The approach was not that Australia should withdraw from its international obligations but, on the contrary, that Australia should acknowledge and accept them, should cover them explicitly in the foreign aid vote, should maybe double the present numbers but, having done so, should provide those places on a government to government basis as part of our regional and international obligations and at no cost to the students. This would be a significant improvement on the present scheme.

The present scheme provides government to government aid but it has been mainly for postgraduate places. The subsidy for private overseas students until now has been a partial subsidy for many people, not a complete subsidy. It has been universal in the sense that all overseas students have been able to avail themselves of the partial subsidy and it has been hidden; that is to say, it has not been made explicit just what contribution is being made, on the basis of proper international obligations, by the taxpayers of this country.

Two reports were produced for the Government in the last couple of years-the first by Professor Jack Goldring, the Dean of Law at Macquarie University. That report was entitled the `Review of Private Overseas Students Policy'. The other was a chapter in a report produced by a committee headed by Sir Gordon Jackson. They took completely different views. The Goldring report suggested-correctly, by the way, I believe-that Australia gains much from the participation in our education system of students from our region and from other countries outside our region. We gain in many ways; no one contests that. Professor Goldring, in attempting to deal with the problems that existed within the system, came up with what were extremely inadequate and inappropriate solutions and recommendations. He recommended, for example, spreading the overseas students rather more thinly and limiting the total enrolment in any particular faculty, but he did not refer to what were the underlying structural problems-that is, if one offers a subsidy in the name of international obligation, in the name of benefiting our region, it should be explicit, and it should be on a government to government basis, and it should be complete for those students. We think that government to government places for students from overseas should be supported by the foreign aid vote and should be outside the educational budget. Students who come in under those provisions should be additional to the quota of places provided for resident Australians. In one step that would end many of the problems we have on Australian campuses today.

The private overseas students, of course, are a different group. The private overseas students who study in Australia are, by definition, those not covered by government to government arrangements. Having adopted the Jackson approach and having said that that is how we should handle the government to government students, the next question is: How do we decide what is the correct way, the fair way, to handle the provision of places for people who are other than government to government students-the private overseas students? We believe it is appropriate to seek to encourage their enrolments and participation, but to have them pay for the services they receive because, after all, they are not part of our foreign aid effort. Our foreign aid effort has been made, or should be made, explicit and separate, and it should be generous. We should therefore seek to encourage the enrolments of other private overseas students, to have them pay for their places, and to allow them to be enrolled in Australian universities-again separate from the quota provided for resident Australians. In this way the displacement of local students from our tertiary institutions by overseas students would end and, if it ended, much of the difficulty we face on campus today, much of the quite ugly racist tension and many of the racist slogans we see on campus would go because Australian students could no longer feel that they were being displaced by overseas students, and they would not be displaced any longer.

This is why the Opposition parties have favoured the approach of Sir Gordon Jackson and have tended not to favour the approach of Professor Jack Goldring. We have much regard for Professor Jack Goldring. We think that on this matter he got it wrong and Sir Gordon Jackson got it right. Professor Goldring offered no relief from the problems; rather, he sought to hide them by recommending a dispersal of private overseas students between a greater number of campuses. He confused the problems of government-sponsored and of private overseas students. We commend the Government for having shown a disposition to support Sir Gordon Jackson's recommendations. They are the better recommendations.

The second issue which must be considered in looking at this legislation is: What is the appropriate rate at which a government should move towards full cost recovery for that group of students who are private overseas students? It is a much more practical question. It involves issues of fairness and issues of efficiency. Let us look first at the question of fairness, particularly at the situation facing some private overseas students in which they believe that they may face sudden and unpredictable increases in charges for the courses in which they are already enrolled. We handled this matter in the Senate last year. I recall that I moved successfully, with the support of the Australian Democrats, for the insertion of a 15 per cent ceiling on the amount by which the fees could increase annually. We moved an amendment which limited to 15 per cent the annual increases in fees for students who were already enrolled in courses. We took the view that anyone coming here after the passage of the legislation would have had a clear indication of the intention of this Government, and that it was the students who were already enrolled that we wished to support and protect.

The present legislation does reflect the effect of that amendment. The Government has increased fees for existing enrolled students by 15 per cent. We believe that, in regard to new enrolments after the Government's action in 1985, there was adequate notice of the Government's intention and that it is not necessary, either on equity grounds or for any other reason, to modify the Government's intention, whatever it is, for students hoping to come here now as new students under the new rules. So the rather large increases proposed for new students in this legislation, whatever we think of them, are not an ambush. They were signalled a year ago. They are not entirely unexpected. They are steps along the road to full cost recovery. Whether or not we would have introduced them, they are consistent with what we laid down last year as the de minimis position in terms of equity which we were seeking to have achieved.

They will not remove the three class structures for private overseas students which now exist. So we now have those who are on full fees-those students who, since 1985 at least, have been permitted to come here on full fees; I do not know whether any actually are here, but that possibility was written in by the Government-those on part fees at the new and higher rate, and those on part fees at the controlled rate, a rate controlled by the work of the Senate last year. We do not applaud the Government for its clumsiness or its harshness in the way in which new students will find themselves facing very--

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be mean, Senator. Give us a bit of a clap.

—I am sorry that Senator Button feels so sensitive about this matter. But new overseas students will face considerable difficulties as a result of the Government's Budget decisions. But at least the Government has acted in line with the signals-whatever one might think of the signals-it sent last year.

SPEECH.PARA: For those reasons we do not oppose this legislation. We still, however, come back to the new vision of tertiary education which we are seeking and which we want to see characterised by a belief in excellence, by a belief in choice, by better access to tertiary education, by greater flexibility in provision of tertiary education, and by more accountability. We believe that, if we wish to increase access, it must be possible for those from overseas who wish to come here and pay their way so to do. They can go to North America and seek to pay their way-whether or not it is subsidised to some extent, as Senator Macklin pointed out last night-and they can go to England and seek to pay their way. They should be able to come to this country and do the same thing.

Our vision seeks to encourage as many as possible from our region to seek their education here rather than in North America or the United Kingdom. We would like to see many of them here as guests. We would like to see many of them here as part of arrangements between governments. We would like to see them here paying no fees. As part of our obligations to our region and to the world, we would like to see them here receiving their education as guests of the Australian public. We would like that done, however, openly, on a government to government basis, as part of our foreign aid effort. We would like to see many others here who do not come under those arrangements. We would like to see them here on a fee-paying basis. We believe such an arrangement will enhance the community goodwill which will flow to Australia. It will benefit Australia by giving us exposure to many people who will enrich our university and college life. It will enhance the quality and range of our tertiary education, and it is a Liberal government that will provide such a system and seek such a freeing up. Having said that, the Opposition supports the overseas student charge legislation and does not intend, however much sympathy we may have, to support any amendments which would go further than we went last year in laying down limits upon the Government as to how it may, in its wisdom, increase or vary the fees which private overseas students have to pay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are opposed to the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill and the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill. As the Opposition has already indicated that it will support the Government on these Bills, we propose nevertheless, since we will have a Committee stage, to move some amendments at that stage. I would like to spell out why we believe that the Government is on a track which is not beneficial to Australia and which ultimately will be detrimental to our interests. The Bills, particularly the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill, propose higher charges for overseas students and extend that charge to students who hitherto have not been liable for such a charge.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Government foreshadowed in 1985-Senator Peter Baume has already pointed this out-the overseas student charge for higher education students who commenced their courses in 1986 will now move to 45 per cent of full average costs from 1987. For new higher education students the rate will also be 45 per cent of full average costs, and students who commenced their study prior to 1985 will pay a 15 per cent increase in 1987, bringing that charge to the equivalent of 32 per cent of full average costs. From 1987, the charge is also to be extended to overseas students in schools and colleges of technical and further education. TAFE students who have commenced their courses prior to 1 January 1987 will pay 32 per cent of the average Commonwealth contribution to TAFE costs, and new students will pay 45 per cent. Secondary students will pay a flat rate of $300 a year. For higher education courses-that is, for university and advanced education courses-the overseas student charge from 1 January 1986 will now be $3,850 per student in medicine, dentistry and veterinary science, and $3,056 for students in other courses. Overseas students who commenced their courses after 1 January 1986 will be paying $5,506 per student in medicine, dentistry and veterinary science, and $4,666 for students in other courses.

Because of the debate we had last night, I think it is important that people know at this juncture that overseas students in higher education will be paying the $250 fee. This charge, of course, is incorporated into the fees I have already mentioned. If the administration charge had not been introduced, the overseas student charge for students commencing courses before 1 January would have been $4,100 or $3,306 or, for those who commenced after 1 January 1986, $5,756 and $4,916. So there has been a shuffle with regard to the overseas student charges. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) last night said that overseas students would not pay the fee. That is not the case; it has been incorporated into the charges.

The equity with regard to these charges certainly should be questioned. I believe that there is a danger that the charge is reaching, or may already have reached, a level where students from low income families will no longer be able to afford an Australian education. In other words, we are now looking at students coming from wealthy overseas families who will, of course, be able to afford the average cost, with subsidies of probably up to 55 per cent. The level of the charge and/or its administration, I believe, is acting as a disincentive to students to embark on an education here. I think this has been accepted by the Government, if one looks at the Budget Papers. Budget Paper No. 1 states that the increased charges to apply in 1987 are estimated to yield an additional $7.3m in revenue `after allowing for reductions in overall student numbers compared with 1985-86'. In other words, the Government knows that it is cutting back on the absolute numbers as well because of these charges.

Unrealistic assumptions are being made of the extent to which our education system can be marketed overseas simply to earn foreign currency. When Australian fees reach a certain level the benefits of an Australian education drop compared with the status of an American or British education for what might in fact be marginal additional costs. This applies at least for wealthy families in the region. Meanwhile, the poorer families, of course, increasingly will miss out. The report of the Goldring Committee of Review of Private Overseas Students Policy, which was delivered in 1984, pointed out that most overseas students come from families which are not wealthy by Australian standards. Hence, I think we are impinging on a significant group.

It is unfortunate that we will be moving into the more elitist area with our education, which of course is still subsidised. I believe that the Indian institutions will become much more attractive, particularly to students from Malaysia and Hong Kong. Since the Indian institutions do not differentiate between home students and those from abroad and all government and grant-aided higher education institutions charge the same low level of fees to all students, and since the subsidies in the Indian circumstances are over 90 per cent for medicine, 75 per cent for engineering and 70 per cent for other graduate courses, fairly obviously those institutions will now be much more attractive than those in Australia. I believe that increasingly that will put India in a position to be of major assistance and it will, of course, allow India, in terms of its foreign affairs, to be much more successful than Australia in years to come.

The question is whether our overseas student system is becoming one that will neither provide assistance to the poor and middle class students of developing countries, with all the intangible but real benefits that come to Australia from their education, nor generate much foreign income, as the so-called hard-headed economic rationalists take over and run this Government. The Opposition has declared in this debate its intention, if it comes to government, to raise the private overseas student charge to full cost recovery by the mid-1990s, as a reiteration of that which was mentioned in the House of Representatives. The charge will be paid directly to the institutions and the aid component of education for overseas students would be provided solely and directly through the Australian Development Assistance Bureau of the Department of Foreign Affairs in the form of a government to government scholarship. That is to say, education aid would go through that government to government mechanism rather than through the present mixture of ADAB-funded students and private overseas students.

Those who support totally going through a government to government scholarship system only would argue that subsidised private education student schemes advantage students from wealthier families to too great an extent. We believe there are problems also with the government to government scholarships because they are prone to policies of patronage by receiving governments, no matter how insistent the donor government-and no matter how insistent our Government-might be on the type of students it would ideally like to see gain from the scholarships. A generously subsidised private overseas students scheme will provide access to students from poorer families in developing countries to an Australian education system, and we believe that this would be of great advantage to Australia. In passing, it is interesting to note that New Zealand in May this year abolished its overseas student fee for quota students, New Zealand, like India, also seeing the advantage that can come from attracting overseas students and providing that support to them. All senators would know and have experience of significant overseas projects which have been very economic to Australia because the people conducting them have had their education in Australia. That goes without saying. We are possibly cutting off our nose here to spite our face.

On the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill, in the Committee stage we intend to seek the support of the Opposition to reduce the burden by allowing students to make payments in four equal instalments throughout the year. We are concerned that this Bill extends the liability for the payment of the overseas students charge to holders of overseas post-graduate student scholarships and other awards. We are totally opposed to such an extension. It will damage research and teaching in Australian universities and, more generally, damage Australia's contribution to the exchange of ideas between different countries. I think the short term financial gains from this extension are highly dubious. The extension of the charge to this category of student means that either the number of awards offered will be reduced so that the remaining awards can be increased in value to cover the charge, or that scholarships will no longer be attractive to gifted students as they will have to pay more than half their stipend to the Government simply to pay the visa fee. The chief effect of the Bill as it stands will be to extend liability for the charge to holders of new post-graduate scholarships awarded by Australian institutions, new students provided with awards by Australian institutions and new students provided with awards by Commonwealth departments or authorities granted after 1 January this year.

It also removes exemption for holders of post-graduate scholarships from the Australian-American Education Foundation. Existing as well as new students on Foundation awards are to pay the charge. Of course, the Bill exempts a number of categories-holders of scholarships awarded by United Nations agencies and Commonwealth and secondary school students under short term exchange schemes, as provided, for example, by Rotary. The latter category was included in the Bill which was introduced in the House of Representatives. I raised this matter here with the Minister for Education. She said that that had not been the intention, although the Bill introduced in the House of Representatives showed that it was the intention. The Government moved an amendment in the House of Representatives in line with the Minister's statement to the Senate so that those categories are now exempt.

It is illogical to require Australian-American Education Foundation scholarship holders who begin study before 1 January 1987 to pay the charge while holders of university granted scholarships are not liable until after 1 January. I am not sure whether this is a pay back to the Americans because of trade or what it is, but it seems a bit odd. What post-graduate students do in universities, and particularly their role in teaching, and the repercussions of the legislation on them, may not have been evident to some of the Minister's advisers. Such students have always played a very important, and increasing, role in teaching. If their teaching function in universities is lessened because of this charge, there will have to be more face to face contact by university staff. That will take them out of their research and significant problems will come from this. I should like to quote various people from universities as to the type of effect these people who actually work at the coal face, as distinct from the bureaucrats who draw up these types of Bills, see in the introduction of such charges. Professor Lennon, Dean of Earth Sciences at Flinders University, has said:

Over the last decade, reduction in financial resources available within universities has resulted in significant staff reductions, thus making it more and more difficult for staff to devote adequate time to personal research effort as well as to teaching. In recent years, many research projects have continued to be pursued successfully only because of involvement of research students. Another effect, perhaps not very widely recognised outside the departments involved, concerns teaching. As reductions in university funding began to bite, some of the earliest casualties were junior fixed-term academic appointments (tutors, demonstrators, senior tutors and senior demonstrators). Science and Engineering teaching generally involves a very long commitment to tutorial and practical classes and many of the front-line teaching staff positions in these areas have disappeared. Most departments have managed to continue such classes until now, mainly through strong part-time support by postgraduate students. If the supply of able postgraduate students were to dry up, our system of practical and tutorial classes is likely to be at risk.

This is interesting considering the problems with science and engineering that Australia is suffering, which have been documented extensively, oddly enough, by the Minister for Science, Mr Jones, in the other place in recent times. This is a most extraordinary situation. Also, Professor Clyne, of the German Department at Monash University, pointed to another area which people might not think would be damaged. He said:

Many of our own graduate students study abroad on scholarships provided by overseas governments or universities. Some of them are engaged in research on languages other than English and need this experience to perfect their language skills--

I interpose that a number of those students are involved in Australia in studying Aboriginal languages and they study overseas to perfect the skills that are necessary for the study of Aboriginal languages. Professor Clyne continued:

Such scholarships are not, on the whole, subject to reciprocity by Australia. It would be unreasonable to expect foreign countries to let our students study at their universities free of charge if we impose such exorbitant fees on our visiting scholarship holders.

That problem has not impinged on the bureaucrats or the Minister, or they have chosen to ignore it. In a very interesting Science Show on 22 November 1986 Professor Fred Smith, Head of the Department of Physics at Monash University, referring to the problems with engineering and science in particular, put the situation clearly when he said, amongst various other things:

In the face of this massive, long-term shortage of trained personnel, the Federal Government appears determined to shoot itself in the head by placing many areas of university research in jeopardy through the extension of the overseas student charge to encompass higher degree candidates receiving university scholarships. Approximately 40 per cent of university research is conducted by postgraduate students undertaking higher degree studies.
He went on to say:

Currently approximately one in five postgraduate students in science and engineering is from overseas. These students have become vital to the continuity of research programs essential for the training of Australia's future R and D workforce. It would be wrong to believe that the benefit lies entirely with the students. The stark reality is that without them research in certain areas, much of which has potential commercial benefit, would cease.

Research programs require several years from conception to reach fruition, extending well beyond the candidature of an individual student. It is essential for the continuity of the program that there are succeeding generations of graduate students who have the opportunity to benefit from the skills and expertise of their more senior colleagues.

This would not be possible without overseas students. Aside from the direct benefits that Australia derives from the research undertaken by overseas graduate students, the training they receive here further establishes the links with the research communities in their home countries. These have been instrumental in establishing Australia's prominence in the Asia-Pacific scientific community. The barrier that the overseas student charge will place before the very highly qualified applicants from the People's Republic of China-
I raise that in particular because the Minister was there recently making a lot of rhetorical statements-
is particularly inappropriate at a time when the Australian Government is actively promoting stronger industrial links between the two countries.

I think that is an item for which we will pay dearly in the years to come. It is another of the short-sighted operations which is damaging our relationship with a country which is incredibly important to our development and our links in this region. I finish the quotes from Professor Smith by referring to something which I think is absolutely true. He said:
But in the case of the post graduate students, I believe quite honestly that they are bringing more benefit to the country than the actual benefits that they are taking away.

Anybody who has had anything to do with teaching in universities in recent times will know that that is perfectly true. I have alluded to holders of post-graduate awards from the Australian-American Education Foundation who come from America to study in Australia and get a stipend of about $8,100 which is roughly equivalent to that paid to the holders of Australian Government post-graduate awards. An extension of the charge will not affect many students but again I believe that it makes little sense. As far as I have been able to establish about 12 Americans who are studying or are about to study will be picked up by this charge. I understand it is probable that the Foundation will bear the liability for the charge for existing award holders in Australia and possibly for those about to take up the 1987 awards, should these students no longer be exempt. Of course, that is the case. If the Foundation does this, surely it will have to reduce the levels of its other awards or the number allocated. This could include awards made to Australians studying in the United States. According to the Foundation's report for 1985 released in September this year a total of 32 Australians were assisted in their studies in the United States by the Foundation. Twelve Americans are assisted here and 32 Australians are assisted there. Who will suffer? It will be the Australians.

The funds for both awards-awards to Americans who come to Australia and Australians who go to the United States-are out of the same pool. That pool is administered by the Australian-American Education Foundation in Canberra. Quite frankly, I do not think we can squeal too much because, if we look at page 107 of Budget Paper No. 6, we see that the estimates for the Foundation are $240,000. Let us then look at the agreement in Article 10 under which these funds are given. Article 10 of the agreement between the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia and the Government of the United States of America provides for the financing of certain education and cultural exchange programs and fees are made available. That Article very clearly states that we shall:
. . . make available to the Foundation one half of the new funds needed to finance the approved annual budget.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the article.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Article 10

Funds and property of the United States Education Foundation in Australia derived from sums made available to such Foundation by the Government of the United States of America pursuant to the Agreement of November 26, 1949, as amended, shall be available to the Foundation to be used for the purposes of this agreement.

The Government of the Commonwealth of Australia shall, as and when requested by the Government of the United States of America for the purpose of this agreement, make available to the Treasurer of the United States of America such portion of the funds provided for in the Agreement of November 26, 1949, as amended, as has not been made available to the Treasurer of the United States of America by the time such agreement is terminated and superseded by this agreement.

In addition to the funds described in the preceding paragraphs, there may also be used for the purposes of this agreement any other funds held or available for expenditure by either Government for such purposes and contributions to the Foundation from any source.

Beginning in the financial year 1964-65 (United States fiscal year 1965) the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia and the Government of the United States of America shall each make available to the Foundation one half of the new funds needed to finance the approved annual budget. The performance of the commitments made in the preceding sentence shall be subject to the availability of appropriations to the Secretary of State when required by the laws of the United States of America, and to such internal procedures as may be required by the laws of the Commonwealth of Australia.

All such funds and any accruals, as interest or otherwise, arising from investment or other use thereof shall be available for expenditure by the Foundation for purposes of the present agreement, within the budgetary limits established pursuant of Article 3 hereof.

TALK.START.PARA: —So we are not paying our full way and we have not pulled our full weight. We are now down to about 40 per cent of that funding and the United States is paying 60 per cent. So when our students in the United States are damaged I do not think we will have a leg to stand on. We really will not be able to squeal and Australian students will suffer yet again.

SPEECH.PARA: The final category of student holders we are concerned with are those in receipt of awards by Commonwealth departments or agencies. These include schemes such as the Commonwealth scholarship and fellowship plan which is administered by the Department of Education, in the case of those students from developed Commonwealth countries such as Canada, and by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau in the case of students from other countries. I understand that the imposition of the charge in such cases will almost certainly reduce the number of scholarships available. The relevant departments will pay the charge out of the funds reserved for the awards. Those who are still getting the awards will not have to bear the cost of the charge. But to achieve this situation there will have to be fewer awards. It is a pity that only a certain number of students are currently able to take up those awards. The overall situation is that our best students are the ones likely to be affected-that is, students who receive institutional and Commonwealth awards. I think it is a pity that we will be able to afford fewer of those people who will provide the backbone for Australia's research and development. Overseas students are not the only ones who will be affected. Graduate and undergraduate students will be affected because of the reduction in teaching capacities in our universities and colleges of advanced education.

Australia has argued very strongly in the international market-place for a free flow of, for example, its agricultural products and an imposition of free trade in that area. I had hoped that Australia would have been in the forefront in attempting to get these types of student exchanges acknowledged by the various countries. I believe that the extensions contained in the Overseas Students Charge Collection Bill will inhibit that type of flow and the type of work that Australia is doing in the international arena. I think it is likely to bring Australia into difficulties with a whole range of other countries and I think the long term effects will certainly outweigh the short term financial benefits that the Government is seeking to gain.

As I have already mentioned, I am particularly concerned about the circumstances between ourselves and China. In anybody's terms China must be seen as one of the major areas that we have to develop. I had hoped that the Minister's recent trip to China would have deflected the impact of the charge, at least in that area. Unfortunately, that has not been the case. I think we will suffer extensively and, to our detriment, these students will be picked up by New Zealand which has removed its charge and they will be picked up by India which, as I have already pointed out, has very low charges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate. The purpose of the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1986 and the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill 1986 is to set the level of charge for overseas students coming to Australia to study. Although there is a variety of views about how this program should best be handled I must say that, at one level, I am pleased that there is agreement amongst honourable senators that the overseas students program is important to Australia, to the host countries and to relations in the region. There is not any argument suggesting that the program should be abandoned. The fact that there is general approval of the program is an important development. However, there are different views about how the program can best be handled and can best be paid for. I understand that Senator Peter Baume still favours the Jackson approach arising from the report of the Jackson Committee on Overseas Aid which, in summary terms, is charging all students full costs and then having a series of scholarships. That is not the line that our Government chose to pursue for reasons that I have stated many times and I will not take up the time of the Senate by restating them now.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it is important to remember that we are still very substantially subsidising a program for overseas students. The cost of the subsidised program next year will be in the vicinity of $88m. Despite the sorts of criticisms that Senator Macklin might have about our commitment to our region I do not think there can be any argument that that is a substantial commitment to the educational development of our region and one that we intend to maintain. The size of the program not only is being maintained through additional policies, such as the opportunity for overseas students to study in Australia on a full cost basis, but also, generally, is being expanded quite dramatically. The subsidised program is remaining at the very high level it was when we came into office. We are simply requiring students to make a greater contribution than was originally the case. We need to do that for economic reasons.

I do not think any honourable senator would suggest that the Government has revenue available to it to maintain an entirely free access or nearly free access to Australia for overseas students. It is no longer possible for a government to do that. I believe that we have balanced all considerations and come up with a very fair and practical way of continuing what has been and will continue to be a very successful program. I point out too that, despite the kind of criticism Senator Macklin has made, we have no evidence at all that there has been any drop in demand for the subsidised places. It seems that there are still very large numbers of students in our region who are prepared to make the contribution required by us to their university or college place in Australia.

I remind honourable senators and those listening to the debate that we are still subsidising 55 per cent or more, depending on when the students started their courses, of the cost of overseas students studying in Australia. Given the pressures on our Government in the education area, I think any fair assessment would be that that is still a substantial contribution. Senator Macklin seems to be in some confusion about the relationship between the $250 administration charge and the cost to subsidise overseas students. In fact, there will be no extra cost arising from the charge to overseas students. What will happen is--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say there was an extra cost.

—I think it would be desirable if Senator Macklin were to listen rather than interject because he has clearly misunderstood, as he so often does, the procedures for implementation of the policy. What will happen is that the overseas student charge--
—Tell us the last policy you implemented.

—I do not need to explain to Senator Peter Baume, because I think he understands it. The Australian Democrats are determined to shout and scream and not to listen to the explanation. Nonetheless, for the sake of the record, I will persist in the explanation. The overseas student charge will be discounted by $250. The student will pay the $250 but the charge will have been discounted. So there is no net additional cost to the student but, for reasons of administrative efficiency, the charge will actually be handed over by the overseas students, but it will be discounted.

SPEECH.PARA: There is general agreement and agreement by the coalition parties that the legislation should go through. There is a variety of views about how we can best maintain and develop our overseas students program but, essentially, I think all honourable senators accept the value and worth of the program. I thank them for their consideration.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the interweaving of the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill and the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill my amendments (2), (3) and (4) to the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill are really connected to the amendments that I wish to move to the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill. There are really only two issues involved in all of these amendments. I seek leave to move all the amendments to both Bills together and suggest that we simply deal with the two issues separately. I think that is the simplest way of doing it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the following amendments to the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 4, paragraph 6 (a), proposed new sub-section 6 (4), lines 25 to 27, leave out ``(not being a post-graduate student who is the holder of a scholarship awarded by the Australian-American Educational Foundation)''.
(2) Pages 4 and 5, paragraph 6 (a), proposed new sub-section 6 (4a), lines 39 to 44 and 1 to 15, leave out the sub-section, insert the following new sub-section:

`` `(4a) For the purposes of this section, an overseas student who is enrolled in a technical and further education course for a year (in this sub-section referred to as the ``enrolment year'') is an eligible overseas student in relation to the enrolment year if the student-
(a) was enrolled in a technical and further education course before 1 January 1987; and
(b) was or is enrolled in-
(i) that course; or
(ii) if the student has, on one or more occasions, transferred his or her enrolment to another technical and further education course-that other course,
for the enrolment year and for each year after 31 December 1986 and before the enrolment year.' ''.
I move the following amendments to the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill:
(1) Page 1, after clause 2, insert the following new clause:
``2a. Section 4 of the Principal Act is amended-
(a) by inserting in sub-section (1) ``sub-sections (3) and (4) and' after `to';
(b) by adding at the end the following sub-sections:
`(3) The charge in respect of the enrolment of an overseas student in a prescribed course for a year may be paid in four equal instalments and, in that case-
(a) the first instalment is due for payment by the student on the day on which the whole of the charge would otherwise have been due for payment in accordance with sub-section (1);
(b) the second instalment is due for payment by the student on 15 May in that year;
(c) the third instalment is due for payment by the student on 15 July in that year; and
(d) the fourth instalment is due for payment by the student on 15 September in that year.

`(4) Where, but for this sub-section, the amount of an instalment would be an amount that includes a fraction of a cent, the last instalment in a year is increased by the least amount that will result in the earlier instalments for that year being equal instalments of an amount that does not include a fraction of a cent.'.''.
(2) Page 1, clause 3, proposed new paragraph 4a (1) (a), line 16, leave out ``before 1 January 1987''.
(3) Page 1, clause 3, proposed new paragraph 4a (1) (a), line 17, leave out ``and who commenced that study before that date''.
(4) Page 3, clause 4, leave out the clause.

I wish to speak only briefly to the amendments I have moved to the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill as I will rehearse the arguments at the Committee stage. Amendments (2), (3) and (4) are consequential on the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill. I have read out a number of extensive quotations. Will the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) respond to the problem expressed by many people in tertiary institutions concerning overseas students-who are, as I point out, one in five of all students-who pick up a lot of work demonstrating as tutors and carry a lot of the load in terms of research?

TALK.START.PARA: —The views of many institutions have certainly been conveyed to me. Concern has been expressed that the effect of imposing the charge on post-graduate students will be a decline in the research effort. I am treating these concerns very seriously. I have asked the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee to monitor the effect very carefully so that if there is such a diminution of research effort, as has been predicted, the Government will have this information available and will be in a position to review that particular aspect of the charge.

—I thank the Minister. I presume that such a review will take place towards the end of an academic year. If this turns out as predicted, I imagine that the Minister will then be looking at a review for the next academic year?
—Yes, I expect that preliminary information will be available by about April, which will be in time for the Government to take steps in the Budget should it make that decision.

—I thank the Minister. I wish now to refer to the other topic which is really almost solely contained within the Overseas Students Charge Collection Amendment Bill. I refer to the way in which this charge might be able to be paid. Since the charge is there and since the Minister and the Department of Education in particular have been involved in what can only be called some very unfortunate incidents in terms of deporting people who are studying in Australia because of non-payment of fees-a visa charge-I would have thought that it is in the interests of the Government and of the students to come up with a more satisfactory way of payment. I remind honourable senators that the amounts we are now talking about are considerable even in Australian terms. I think most Australian families will be hard pressed to come up with that amount of money in one hit.
—What are you suggesting?

—My suggestion in these amendments is that payment be made in four instalments over the year. The idea of the instalment system is two-fold: Fairly obviously it will lessen the burden at any particular time and will also do something in terms of the Government's invidious situation with regard to deportations. I would have thought that if there was an instalment operation the leeway between one instalment payment and the next could be taken as the grace time, as it were. When a student got to, say, the second or the third instalment period, whatever it happened to be, and had not paid the previous instalment, it would be obvious to the student, his family and the Government that that student would not be in a position to be able to afford the fees over that year. What happened in a case that the Minister knows well is that the student was finally able to come up with that money a day or two later. But getting all that money together must be an enormous burden for many families. I would have thought that since this will be almost, but not quite, revenue neutral it might alleviate the Government of that type of embarrassment. It is an embarrassment not only to the Government but also to Australia because it does not give us good publicity in papers in overseas countries. It will also assist students and their families in meeting these ever rising costs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many problems with the amendment proposed by Senator Macklin to allow students to pay the charge four times a year. It would quadruple the administrative burden on the overseas students State offices and on the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs regional offices. Those two offices would have to process each student's case four times a year rather than once a year, so it would be increasing the work load by four; defaulting students would have to be pursued for four instalments, increasing the burden of recovery action; termination of studies for non-payment of the charge would be complicated; the application of the refund provisions would be more complicated; and staff increases would be required to meet the increased work load. Additional automatic data processing hardware and software would be required to monitor the payment of the charge made in instalments.

SPEECH.PARA: On balance, the Government's view is that it is not appropriate for the Australian taxpayer to be asked to pay for the additional administrative costs which would be involved in increasing fourfold the administration of the program. The students are already in receipt of a substantial subsidy from the Australian taxpayer. We think that in the present circumstances it is not fair to ask the taxpayer to subsidise the program even further. Overseas students know quite well in advance the level of the charge they will be required to meet. They have to organise their finances well in advance in any event. While in Australia they are able to earn money to pay their living expenses. They know what their tutorial expenses are well in advance. Despite the fact that there would be some attractions to Senator Macklin's suggestion the overall administrative burden and cost cannot justify our acceptance of that proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I probably could agree with the last reason that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) gave-that we would have to change the software. But we could probably get that done free of charge if the Minister really wanted to. The other comments do not bear much looking at. The costs of changing the software would be almost minimal. The vast bulk of students pay on time on entry. We are talking only about a small number of people. We already have difficulties with a small number and, under my proposal, we would be in difficulties with a small number. I do not believe the Yes, Minister response is reasonable in terms of the problems these students are facing. The marginal additional cost that would have to be borne would easily be justified in terms of the excessively bad Press that Australia has been receiving in overseas countries. As the Minister has already pointed out, we are still subsidising these students to the tune of 55 per cent but that does not seem to be having much effect on the type of image that we have managed to create over the deportations. My interest is both to alleviate the burden on the students and, more particularly, to avoid the unseemly circumstances of jettisoning students who have come here to study and the effect that that has on our relationships with their countries.

—The Opposition has indicated that for various reasons it will not support the amendments should we divide on the matter. But Senator Macklin's argument puts in the balance on the one side issues of fairness and on the other side the Minister's response about government efficiency.
—And cost.

—There are issues of cost and efficiency. Senator Macklin's argument is not without merit. These amendments try to provide for greater fairness in trying to meet the needs of students. I only ask the Minister to take Senator Macklin's general proposition back for further study. After all, we are asking a Labor government to do this. If there is an issue of equity which may be improved will the Minister put it under study in the hope that she may come up with some way of meeting-if not with Senator Macklin's formula with some other formula-the general proposition Senator Macklin put to seek to overcome the general problems? I add just one more thing. I do not believe that some of the publicity that has occurred with certain deportations has been fair or warranted. It is not our business to be defenders of the Government but I put on record that I cannot see any other course open to the Government if people do not pay the prescribed fee. The proposition that four equal payments may enhance the capacity to pay of people who study here is not without merit. It should be given more attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Peter Baume for his constructive approach to this matter. As I have admitted, there is some merit in the suggestion of students being able to pay by instalments. The suggestion was made to me by representatives of overseas students a couple of months ago. We looked at the matter. I am happy to say that we will look at it again. We rejected it after having examined, in terms of the Budget, the administrative costs involved. But there is no reason why we cannot look at it again, as Senator Peter Baume has suggested. I have recently announced the establishment of an overseas students council with overseas student representation to be chaired by Professor Goldring. It may well be that that council will wish to look at this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of warning I simply say that Senator Macklin seems to think that only a few students would want to take advantage of an instalment plan. Once such a plan existed there is no reason why all students would not want to take part because there would be some financial advantage in their doing so. We would not just be looking at an instalment plan for some students. We are not in a position to judge the relative hardship of students. We would be looking at making this plan available to 18,000 students. The administrative costs would be very high. However, in the spirit of the constructive suggestion that has been made I will certainly undertake to see whether it is possible to have a cost efficient instalment plan made available to students.

I also thank Senator Peter Baume for his comments on media reports surrounding deportations. He said that they were unfair. I agree. I remind the Committee, too, that every year about 18,000 overseas students study in Australia. The maximum number that might end up having to return home, being deported, in a year would be no more than a half a dozen. One can get entirely out of proportion the fact that in some cases students have not kept to the conditions under which they came here and have been sent home. A maximum of half a dozen being deported in a year when 18,000 students study here is not a great number. This does not suggest that there is any harsh application of the deportation provisions.

I refer to bad publicity in host countries. There has been criticism of the program from time to time. I have been in the region and have had discussions with governments and the media. Some criticism is inevitable, as it is in Australia, where any increase in any cost will attract criticism from some groups and attract media coverage. There is criticism, for example, in the Malaysian Press about increases in costs and occasionally about a deportation. I make it clear that the Government of Malaysia has no criticisms of the increase in costs. I have had very extensive discussions with the education Minister, the Prime Minister and others involved. They understand our economic circumstances. They appreciate our need to put up the costs. Honourable senators will notice that there is no government criticism. Criticism arises as it does anywhere in Australia when any cost or charge goes up. People do not like paying more than they paid the year before. The media will give them a run. I do not attach any greater significance than that to it. As to the effects on our bilateral relations in the region, there is a great deal of appreciation of the program by governments and a desire to see it continue.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Ryan) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION ADMINISTRATION AMENDMENT (RECOVERY OF TAX DEBTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This piece of legislation before the Senate today is yet another example of the incompetence of the Labor Government in its administration of the Australian taxation system. The Taxation Administration Amendment (Recovery of Tax Debts) Bill 1986 can be added to those misguided judgments of the Government with regard to the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and other legislation which it has undertaken in the tax area. The Bill proposes to the Taxation Administration Act 1953 amendments that are purported to be necessary following a decision of the Full Court of the Queensland Supreme Court with regard to an action by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation to recover an unpaid taxation debt. The Court, by a majority view, held that the time limit specified in the Queensland Limitation of Actions Act 1974 for the commencement of proceedings to recover a debt applied by virtue of section 64 of the Commonwealth Judiciary Act 1903 to proceedings to recover tax debts to the Commonwealth. This decision by the Queensland Supreme Court was contrary to decisions previously taken by Supreme Courts in other States, namely, Western Australia and New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the Acting Treasurer, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), when introducing the Bill into the House of Representatives in September, the Queensland decision was contrary to the long held view that taxation debts would, by virtue of the Crown prerogative, be recoverable at any time. As my colleague the shadow Treasurer, Mr Jim Carlton, pointed out in the debate in the House of Representatives, this is not a long held view and it is misleading for the Government to suggest that it is. I would like to make that point a little clearer later in my remarks.

With regard to the recent Queensland decision, the Commissioner of Taxation has applied to the High Court of Australia for special leave to appeal against the decision of the Queensland Supreme Court. In other words, legal processes are currently in train for the Commissioner to challenge the decision, yet the Government is seeking to pass legislation, the intention of which is to negate the decision of the Queensland Supreme Court, before any appeal is heard in the High Court. Another slight difficulty in discussing the matter, which matter led to the introduction of this Bill, was decided in the Queensland Supreme Court. However, another matter is before the Court of Appeal of the Supreme Court of New South Wales. That Court is in the process of reaching its decision in the matter DTR Securities Pty Ltd v. Deputy Commissioner of Taxation. The Court is presently considering its decision, having announced on 27 June 1986 that it would reserve its decision. It is very important to the functioning of our constitutional arrangements that there be self-restraint by each area of government when it touches on the spheres of others. In this case, the House is being asked to debate a matter which is currently before the Court of Appeal in New South Wales. I think it is grossly improper that the Government be apparently attempting to influence the decision in that Court.

If enacted to operate unconditionally, the Bill will have the effect of retrospectively overturning any judgment of any court in Queensland or any other State court exercising Federal jurisdiction given after 24 September 1986. In short, the Crown, in effect, has sought to stay all proceedings in any court exercising Federal jurisdiction. If this is not the case, any final judgment given against the Commissioner after 24 September 1986 will be rendered negatory if the Bill, when enacted, operates unconditionally. Clearly, the Bill is an attempt to influence the judiciary. Alternatively, if it operates unconditionally, it will override any judgment given for the taxpayer after 24 June 1986.

In introducing the Bill in the House of Representatives, the Minister claimed that, unless prompt legislative action is undertaken, the recovery of many millions of dollars of outstanding tax, mainly from tax avoiders, would at best be delayed by several months and at worst be prevented altogether. Specifically it is claimed that if the rationale for the decision were to apply Australia-wide, revenue of approximately $200m for this financial year and a further $700m in the future would be placed in jeopardy. The Government has argued that a revenue loss of this magnitude cannot be countenanced, that not to act without delay to protect this would be irresponsible. However, the stated rationale for the Bill is contradicted by the inaction to recover outstanding tax debts even within the normal period of six years under the statute of limitations. In other words, the Australian Taxation Office has been grossly irresponsible, it seems, in not proceeding within a six-year period to initiate even the smallest action to recover outstanding amounts owing to the Commonwealth. It has had six years in which to recover or start the process of recovery, but it has failed to do so. It is obviously a gross dereliction of duty.
When the Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives, Mr Hurford said:

The vast majority of the $900m is owed by tax avoidance participants of the 1970s and early 1980s. Over the past five to 10 years, they have resorted to every means available to frustrate the considerable efforts of the Commissioner of Taxation to resolve disputes as to liability and to secure the payment of outstanding tax and penalties,

I fail to recognise the legitimacy of that rationale, which has apparently been adopted by the Commissioner of Taxation, whereby recovery of tax debts is deferred until liability to pay the tax is determined. Even if one accepts this policy stance adopted by the Commissioner, that does not detract from the importance and desirability of the Australian Taxation Office pursuing the recovery of tax debt to the fullest. In this regard, more effective and more efficient means to determine and settle tax liability could be undertaken by the Commissioner of Taxation at any time. It is misleading and mischievous for the Government to suggest that without this Bill hundreds of millions of dollars in tax revenue would be forgone. If the Commissioner of Taxation had sought to take action within six years on any matter that is outstanding the alleged problem would not have arisen. However, through laxity and irresponsible behaviour on the part of the Commissioner of Taxation, this has not been undertaken. Legislation enacted by the previous Liberal-National Party Government to stamp out tax avoidance measures was apparently acted upon in a slothful and less than responsible fashion by the Commissioner of Taxation.

The crux of the matter is that the Government apparently does not consider six years a long enough period even to start the smallest action against taxpayers to recover debts. Notwithstanding the settlement of tax liability, which is a totally different issue, if the Commissioner of Taxation cannot effectively initiate action to recover moneys owing to the Commonwealth within six years, this again calls into question the efficiency of the Tax Office in its administration of the tax laws. While the Commissioner of Taxation has practically unfettered responsibility and powers in the administration of the tax system and the laws pertaining thereto, it is an act of gross misrepresentation by the Government to suggest that more powers are warranted. If he cannot institute recovery procedures within six years of an assessment becoming due and payable, it is unlikely that the greater powers vested in this Bill will correct the laxity and the tardiness of the Taxation Commissioner in initiating action.

I intend to go into this fundamental reason as to why the Government has proposed this legislation and why the Opposition does not support this ill-conceived piece of legislation. To suggest that the Commissioner of Taxation needs a longer period in which to initiate tax recovery procedures against persons who have been assessed to have a tax liability because a settlement of the liability usually precludes the recovery of debt within the statutory time limit is totally misleading and a blatant abdication of responsibilities.

There is ample opportunity for the Commissioner of Taxation to institute proceedings for tax recovery. Section 204 of the Income Tax Assessment Act is express on that matter. Income tax and penalties are payable 30 days after service of the notice of assessment. That requirement is categorical. A taxpayer is required to pay his or her debt within 30 days of receiving an assessment. A taxpayer is obligated to pay the tax, irrespective of whether he or she disputes the excessiveness or otherwise of the liability to pay the tax. In short, a taxpayer is required to pay first and argue later. This requirement is embodied in section 201 (1) of the Act, which provides:

The fact that an appeal or reference is pending shall not in the meantime interfere with or affect the assessment the subject of the appeal or reference; and income tax may be recovered on the assessment as if no appeal or reference were pending.

The Commissioner of Taxation has been lax in his obedience in following those clear directions of the state which he is obligated to administer. The courts have adopted a most stringent view in refusing to grant applications by taxpayers for a stay of recovery of proceedings brought by the Commissioner where the disputed, unpaid tax relates to tax avoidance measures. Hence, the supposed rationale for this Bill falls apart.
Expanding that point, I will quote from a case in which Mr Justice Hutley said:

The fact that a taxpayer may arrange his affairs in any manner consistent with the law provides no justification for a Court giving any assistance to him in his attempts to resist the collection of assessments issued by the Commissioner of Taxation.

In plain English, for the benefit of the Government, neither the Taxation Commissioner nor the Government can claim that tax recovery proceedings have been delayed because of the views expressed by the courts. The intent of the Income Tax Assessment Act and the views subsequently adopted by the courts are a clear instruction to the Commissioner that payment of tax is not to be deferred pending resolution of any appeal or objection to a tax assessment.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Leader of the Government in the Senate that the Treasurer tried to dismiss the September downgrading of Australia's credit rating by Moody's Investor Services Inc. largely on the basis that Standard and Poor's Corporation, which the Treasurer described as the major United States rating agency, had kept Australia at the AAA level. In particular I refer to the Treasurer's comments on 12 September:

QUESTION.PARA: There are a lot of other counter views and obviously the other major rating agency, Standard and Poor's don't hold Moody's view.
The day before that, on the World Today program, the Treasurer said:
. . . Standard and Poor's still has us on AAA so they've made a judgment about the current account . . .

Now that Standard and Poor's has made a judgment on the Australian economy and has agreed with Moody's, I ask: What are the implications of this second downgrading? Does the Minister agree that this bad news further reduces the chance of a fall in interest rates in the near future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I forget Senator Chaney's exact terminology, but I do not agree that Mr Keating as Treasurer, when Moody's downgraded the Australian dollar, gave the fact that Standard and Poor's had not acted similarly as a prime reason-I concede that he used it as a reason, but not as a prime reason-for his comments on the effects of the Moody's re-evaluation. I do not share the view that it was put at the time by the Treasurer, or by anybody else, as being a substantial explanation, although I certainly agree that it was adverted to by the Treasurer on several occasions and was possibly adverted to here in the Senate as well.
—They do not understand.

—I thank the honourable senator. Let me go to the second part of the question, which deals with the alleged consequences of the downgrading. It is most important to look at what Standard and Poor's in fact said in respect of this. Senator Walters might listen to this instead of interjecting. The essence of what Standard and Poor's said was that the Government's economic policies are on the right track, that they are appropriate policies to address the current account deficit, and that the major reason for Australia's continuing position at present is unfavourable external trade developments, particularly the continuing depressed state of our traditional major export markets, the sharp fall in the terms of trade which followed and increasing trade protectionism.
—The fringe benefits tax?

—No, it did not mention that, funnily enough; that is kept for the junior players. It went on to talk about the wide ranging measures introduced by the Government, including a tighter monetary stance, reduced Budget deficits and moderate wage settlements, which have dampened demand. It also went on to refer to extensive economic reforms, including lower income taxes, deregulation of the financial sector and gradual removal of industry protection. All those things were referred to by Standard and Poor's. They might be remote from Senator Walters's little bailiwick down there, but they are things which this agency had to say about the present Government's policies.

ANSWER.PARA: A very important point which it went on to make was that economic adjustments to correct Australia's current account problems will take time; that is, as it went on to say, it will only occur `over the medium term'-that was the expression it used. That is something which has been consistently said by us, and it is quite distinct from the views put forward by the Opposition here in the Senate, and quite distinct from the taking of opportunistic steps in relation even to a late filing of a tax return as being an issue of fundamental importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his explanation of some of the matters put forward by Standard and Poor's. I realise that this is not the time to debate his view on the Treasurer's reliance on Standard and Poor's when Moody's downgraded Australia's credit rating in September, but I just point out to him that on five occasions over 11, 12, and 16 September the Treasurer did in fact rely on the Standard and Poor's rating to support his position. However, I remind the Minister that my question related to the implications for interest rates, which he did not directly address in his answer, although he did say that Standard and Poor's referred with approval to the Government's tighter monetary stance, which, of course, is directly relevant to the question of interest rates. I ask: Does the Minister confirm that the position including the downgrading of our credit rating reduces the chance of a fall in interest rates in the near future?

—I am not sure that it does in itself. I am not any better qualified than any other commentator to put a view about this. The fact of a revised credit rating does not in itself, in my view, affect the outlook for interest rates. The Government has made its position clear on this issue. I would have thought that it is a matter for judgment at the appropriate time as to policies which will affect interest rates. That will be exercised.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen reports that a court in West Berlin has implicated a Syrian official in providing explosives to two persons convicted of a terrorist bombing in that city? Is the Minister able to comment on the consequences of this development and on the measures the Government can take to counter the threat of state-sponsored terrorism, or indeed any form of terrorism?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of reports that two Jordanians having close links to Syria have been convicted in the Federal Republic of Germany of carrying out a bomb attack on the German-Arab Association in West Berlin on 29 November. One of the persons, Ahmed Hasi, is the brother of Nezar Hendawi, who was recently sentenced to 45 years imprisonment for the attempted bombing of an El Al airliner in London.

ANSWER.PARA: Evidence given at the trial clearly indicates Syrian Government involvement in the attack. As a consequence of the trial, four Syrian diplomats have been expelled and the Bonn Government has not determined the date to replace its Ambassador to Syria, who has already left Damascus on the completion of his assignment. Certain Syrians resident in East Berlin will no longer be granted entry to West Berlin following action taken by United States, French and British officials in their sectors of the city.

The Australian Government consistently and unequivocally condemns all forms of terrorism and has welcomed and encouraged the growing resolve on the part of countries threatened by the terrorist menace to work together against it. The relevant government agencies and departments already have substantial counter-terrorist links with a number of countries. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, advised Parliament in May that Australia had initiated a new round of discussions to improve co-operation in the counter-terrorism field. The initial results of these exchanges are currently being considered by other government departments and agencies which share responsibility for counter-terrorist activities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I inform the Minister that documents lodged in the Land Titles Office in Sydney show that $60,000 from the sale of a shop in Paddington was received by the Treasurer on 25 July 1984. I refer the Minister to the Treasurer's statement in the House of Representatives on Friday, and I quoted:

QUESTION.PARA: Whatever appropriate inclusions will go in my tax return of course would have been there, as appropriately they should.
Has the Government inquired, and if not, will it so inquire, as to whether income from this source received by the Treasurer was disclosed in the 15-month late 1984-85 tax return he lodged last week?

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I should say about that is something I have said all along: Despite the desperate efforts of Opposition senators, this is a matter between the Commissioner of Taxation and an individual taxpayer. The assumption by Senator Messner-even if the facts were as stated-is that any such sum of money was in fact income.
—Some or all of it?

—I do not know, but I think that Senator Messner ought to be very careful about some of the assumptions he makes. I am only trying to help. To the extent that the question may be based on false assumptions, I suppose we will be able to bounce it on the Opposition at some time in the future, and we will do that.
—Are you threatening me?
—Yes, I am-very nicely, though. The matter is essentially one between the Commissioner of Taxation and the taxpayer. I have nothing more to add, except to say that it is important--
—What about your BHP shares?
—Order! There are too many interjections.
—Not very good, either, Mr President. That is my problem with them.
—One of your problems.

—The point I was about to make is relevant to Senator Puplick as well as to Senator Messner. It would be a tragedy if on the basis of all these scurrilous and probably false assumptions the Liberal Party continued to degenerate into a name-calling, factionalised body rent by leadership struggles, which bringeth the verdict that when Australia needed the input of Liberals it was not a party of big enough people to answer the call successfully. That is what it is all about. They are not my words, of course; they are taken from the editorial of yesterday's Australian.
